title: 114_s1885
content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veterans for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system. The program must operate in at least six locations, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban/rural settings. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must select locations with high interaction between the Department and community organizations to provide housing and services for homeless veterans. Intensive case management interventions are to be provided to at least 20 covered veterans at each location who receive the most health care services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs selects locations with high interaction between the Department and community organizations to provide housing and services for homeless veterans. Intensive case management interventions are provided to covered veterans to improve housing stability and healthcare appropriateness. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will commence the program for intensive case management interventions by September 1, 2016. A report on the program must be submitted by December 1, 2018, including assessments on types of interventions, housing status, and employment status of veterans who received the interventions. The program for intensive case management interventions started by September 1, 2016, requires a report by December 1, 2018. The report should include assessments on employment status, use of health care services, and costs incurred by veterans who received the interventions. The report on the program for intensive case management interventions must include the number of veterans who received interventions, costs incurred by the Department, and estimates of healthcare costs saved due to the interventions. The report must include the number of veterans who received intensive case management interventions, costs incurred by the Department, and estimates of healthcare costs saved. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness retain housing. Grants will be awarded to organizations with a proven ability to offer these services, with priority given to those experienced in transitional housing. The Secretary will prioritize organizations with experience in providing case management services, especially those successful in offering transitional housing services funded by the Secretary. Extra priority will be given to organizations that voluntarily cease receiving funding for transitional housing and convert their facilities to provide permanent housing meeting quality standards. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for the conversion of facilities funded by grants for construction, rehabilitation, or acquisition without being considered in non-compliance with grant terms. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the act. In 2013, a program was established to help homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness retain housing. In 2014, funding authorization was approved. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must create regulations within a year of the Act's enactment. A report on the program's effectiveness must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019, including data on veterans who retained permanent housing through case management services. The report on the program's effectiveness must include data on veterans who retained permanent housing through case management services, their housing status, reasons for not retaining housing, use of VA housing assistance, and employment status before and after receiving services. An assessment of veterans' employment status before and after receiving case management services under the program. Expansion of housing assistance program for veterans by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. This includes acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy in permanent housing. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for veterans and families by providing permanent or transitional housing and ensuring referrals for benefits and services. The Department of Veterans Affairs is expanding housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans in temporary housing, and very low-income veteran families. They will conduct outreach to educate realtors, landlords, and developers about veterans' housing needs. Additionally, a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans will be established. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to conduct research, assess program effectiveness, and disseminate best practices for addressing veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to identify best practices, integrate evidence-based policies, serve as a resource center, and coordinate information exchange on veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending section 2012 of title 38, United States Code to include a new subsection (e) for reviewing grant recipients and eligible entities' performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income.
